Row.Text: The Necropolis in the capital is now halfway finished. Though a long and productive life is expected for the people's leader, their journey to the afterlife will be unparalleled in its splendor, when at last that day of passage comes.
Build more such monuments across the land.
Artisanal tombs are for the royal family only.
Let us therefore name our capital’s Necropolis the "Valley of the Pharaohs".
Finish the other Unique Quarter building in capital.

One day, a devastating flood rushes through the streets as the river swells its banks. Entire city districts are now dank, hazardous and unlivable, with hundreds now homeless. In every crisis, however, there is an opportunity.
Make space for them in the central quarter.

Camels are ungainly, pungent, and uniquely disagreeable. Nonetheless, the nomads of the desert claim they can cross vast distances carrying heavy loads, with no need for water. If true, the desert may not be so unknowable as once thought.
Ignore the smell and cultivate camels.

Though ugly and difficult to manage, camels turn out to be the ships of the desert. Upon their backs, the people move like the nomads, and from desolation a vast highway emerges in the empty quarter. From the backs of camels, the seas of sand look newly rich with opportunity.
At the borders live the fierce Medjay people, elite warriors who live as nomads. They would be formidable foes, but it seems their intention is peaceful collaboration and service.

We will train our own Egyptian soldiers in the way of the Medjay, and bring their strength into ours. We will have to train these troops rapidly, though – the Medjay may not remain in one place for long.

Though the Medjay do not remain in one place for long, Egyptian soldiers quickly take advantage of the chance to study their strength. Soon, the army is trained in the ways of their fierce nomadic neighbors.
This is how one manages both enemies and allies – no matter how friendly a warrior appears, bear in mind their one purpose is death.
One must remember that a soldier's purpose is death, no matter how friendly the face.
Disperse an Independent Power with a Medjay within {1_turn_timer}.

Though flowers may lie dormant for a decade or more, a rainstorm can bring a sudden eruption of color and light. All things in the desert have their time, and it is now the people's turn to blossom in the new city quarters.
Death lasts longer than life. Memorials of gold and stone celebrate the people's legacy in the present, and stand to tell their story to all who come afterwards.
With every stone laid, the world of the divine, in which humanity walks, is sealed safely off from the realm of beasts.
Let the shepherds come with their yearlings; the altar is for all.
Mark the gates with the divine seal; the city is a space set apart for knowledge.
Make a home for the city goddess at the altar, where she can bless farmers' hoes and warriors' blades alike.
Tend the altar of the goddess; without her favor, the polis cannot thrive.
Let the city be a mirror of the heavens, so that the heavens may send their rain-heavy clouds.
Dreadlocked sadhus and saffron-clad pandits gather around the altar, engrossed in debate.
Of all the altars, let this be the finest, the most beautiful.
The shape of the greatest of gods rises in exquisite construction, casting a long shadow.

Local leaders have heard the raucous cheers of the dhow's sailors at the defeat of their enemies, and wish to build dhows of their own. Soon, numerous engineers are requesting that the dhow remain in port for a time, to be studied as a model.
The sailors' course of plunder should not be stopped.
The sweet, sticky scent of dates seems to be everywhere, and discarded pits line the streets. Citizens grumble that the Medjay spend more time eating than they do patrolling.
Bar the Medjay from the date stores.
Persian boots march past Grecian columns as fire consumes the capital. In story, song, and image, this triumph will be remembered.

In raising animals, one sees the extremes of life's beauty and foulness alike: manure and flies, the sunrise in an egg, baby calves bursting breathless from bloody cauls. People may be inclined to stop eating an animal who is too unclean, or who is loved too much.
Seafarers tell of encounters with beautiful beings, part human, part fish, who lure sailors to watery graves with their enchanting songs.
The people must be warned of this danger.
The impulse to travel the road of life controls the feet of every man, woman, and child. This journey holds many forks – and countless opportunities.
The city is liberated! The enemy flees, abandoning weapons and siege weapons in their wake. This valuable gear is sure to bring a bounty of coins to the city's coffers.
Share the wealth among the people.

As the ship enters the harbor, a sailor points to the sky. All eyes follow his, and work comes to a stop at the sight of the immense bronze legs, torso, and finally the great crowned head towering over the harbor. The Colossus gazes back, holding aloft the light of the city – but to what purpose?
To instill fear in the hearts of enemies.

An elderly couple soaks peacefully in the baths' largest pool. As they lean back and close their eyes, breathing in the fragrant steam, a wave of water overwhelms them. Spluttering and coughing, the two shake their fists at the laughing youngsters who rile up the waters.

An engineer proudly unveils a design for a smaller, lighter ballista that can easily maneuver on the battlefield. Moments later, a rival engineer files a missile straight through the parchment with their own scale model of an immensely powerful, stationary ballista, and a furious argument breaks out.
An unusual red salt crystal is unearthed from the mine, gleaming like a ripe apple. Cooks demand it as a rare ingredient, but they clash with augurs, who claim it as holy ritual salt.

A famous young poet composes a work about Roman history and pens a gory chapter about a necromantic witch. Some say such unholy topics are outside the bounds of taste, although his peers argue such details add thrills to the narrative.

The poet's expressive historical work on Roman history now includes a sequence in which an army is graphically murdered by a diverse population of lethal snakes. The public is divided as to whether or not his catalogue of serpents is biologically accurate.

Two Egyptian nobles argue about which strange food deserves salt the most. One is desperate to improve his stores of hyena meat. The other believes there are tastes to be unlocked in a bitter fruit from a tree in her garden.
Soak the fruit in salt water.
A noble family aims to promote salted hyena meat as a new luxury delicacy, but few are appetized by the scavenger beast. Perhaps this knowledge is best applied elsewhere.
The combination of salt and water has tempered the noble’s bitter fruit. Olives soon become a staple of the Egyptian diet, and everyone marvels at the transformation induced by the saline bath.

The wilderness is now crisscrossed with trade paths, thanks to steadfast camels. The merchants who travel on their humped backs tell of encounters with new communities, who have as many questions and curiosities as they do.
Take in stories from other lands.

On its opening day, the arena vibrates with eager crowds. But as the seats fill for the first event, a guard rushes up to an organizer and whispers frantically in her ear – one of the lions has escaped!
The arena must be closed immediately.

The arena erupts into a panic with the announcement that one of the lions has escaped! Spectators clamor madly for the exits, ignoring distressed organizers' calls for order. There are numerous injuries amid the chaos, even after guards shout to be heard: the lion, frightened by the chaos, has returned to his cage on his own.

Soldiers come upon an anguished shopkeeper whose stall has been smashed to pieces, with chunks of meat strewn all across the road. "There," the shopkeeper cries, pointing an accusatory finger down an alleyway, where a hulking lion feasts contentedly on a cooked chicken, bones and all. The languorous lion seems very pleased with himself.
The lion is a local hero.

Every morning at the crack of dawn, a group of musicians performs the songs of the day in the market street. Their eagerness is unmatched, but some would dare to say their musicianship needs work, sparking fiery debates among philosophers about the nature of music itself.
The arts are for those who have talent.
Even the unskilled should make happy noises.
The luscious scent of the pairidaeza has dwindled of late. Groundskeepers complain that visitors pick too much fruit from the trees, leaving little for others.

Textile workers present lavish new sigil possibilities for the military, and each unit wants to be in charge of the design. The galley sailors are clamoring for an image of a sea serpent, while the spearmen feel a bull would suit them better. The archers have submitted their own crude drawing of a spider.
Order one with a bull on it.
Request a design based on the archers' spider.

An ambitious group of workers unveils their latest project: the biggest wheel ever constructed! But amid the celebrations, the wheel rolls away down a hill, destroying everything in its path. As a crowd gathers to survey the ruined homes, angry cries for compensation drown out the apologies.
Creative risks are worth what they cost.

The people of the conquered village look up to see a new chief standing before them, wreathed in smoke and speaking passionately. "Progress may mean the destruction of the past," she says, "but there is always a new future to be found."
These people will find their purpose in battle.
A path forward will be forged through labor.

The megalith throws a long shadow over the crowds as they gather in the evening light, preparing their beloved chieftain for burial. Funeral songs hum across the quiet landscape as all mourn her passing, with words that honor her courage in battle, and her benevolence toward friend and foe alike.
Her kindness is a lesson to all.

A gift-giving ceremony between two settlements ends in chaos as one chieftain takes offense at an apparently scandalous offering. The giver insists that a chamber pot is indeed a suitable gift: the ultimate symbol of humility in relationships.
Demand a new gift at once.

The bodies of the fallen spearmen are borne through the city streets, mourners trailing in their wake. When they reach the tomb, they will be buried with those gifts they will most need in the afterlife.
The weapons that earned their honor.
The fruits of the harvest they died to defend.
As the warriors are laid to their final rest, their weeping families and grieving comrades place gifts into their graves according to their custom.
Stand their swords upright to capture the equinox.
Place small clay animals in the hands of the dead.
Sea Shells on the Sea Shore
Citizens line the beach, shucking shellfish to collect the dye within. As the piles of shells grow larger, the briny odor becomes overpowering.
Throw the shells back in the ocean.
Sell the shells on the shore.
A bright new dye rocks the textile scene, and some of the craftworkers are jealous, claiming behind their hands that the vivid color combination is only an accident by the inventor's cat.

The shepherd communities keep sacred horses that no one may ride, on pain of grievous punishment. All well and good, until a shepherd has to find lost sheep on foot, and the only explanation for his tired legs is "the old ways."
Sacred doctrines should always be questioned.
It is as it should be.

The shepherd ignores the neighing of the sacred horse, searching for his lost flock on foot. When at last he returns to the farm with nothing, his fellows praise his fortitude in the face of temptation.

The shepherd glances about to make sure no one is near, then leaps astride the forbidden horse. Together, they ride like the wind over hill and dale, until a chorus of baaahs at last leads them to the lost flock. This triumph is dampened by the outrage of the community at the desecration of the horse.
The valleys are dotted with cloud-like shapes, swaying in unsettling patterns. A strange illness seems to be ravaging the local sheep flocks, and the shepherds are at a loss for what to do.
The whole flock must be culled.
The animals may recover in time.
The culling of the sheep leaves many farmers with heavy hearts. But the healthy ones thrive and do not take ill – it seems the painful choice has saved the flock for the long term.
The farmer's daughter cries as her favorite lamb grows still in her arms. Sadly, the result of her father's patience and mercy toward the sick sheep is that now all the animals are ill.
Lines of people have been forming to see a legendary aurochs, somehow born among a farmer's herd of bulls. It is a big horned animal indeed, and locals venerate its raw power.
Spread the aurochs' legend far and wide.
Breed the aurochs with local livestock.
Two vintners, zealous rivals, are looking to settle a bet on which grape has produced the year's most coveted wines: the aromatic Grk or the full-bodied Verdesse?
The casks are full of Grk.
It's never a bad time for wine, whether in the markets or the taverns. Anyone who thinks people are going too far these days must have a case of sour grapes.

Silkworms labor under the gentle care of their minders. Scholars wonder whether they could be domesticated, and made to produce more thread. "But they are living creatures," a gentle worm tender says. "Can we be so sure of their desires?"
A diviner drinks deeply from the wine bowl and makes a proclamation: a sea of unfamiliar faces is on its way!

The influx of cotton means rapid changes for the fashion scene, with new and daring styles now possible. "A sign of truly living well," says the seamstress, "is when we can make clothes expressive, not just practical."
Time to get weird with cotton.
Weavers craft new huipil for travelers, offering visitors patterns of their home. Returning travelers have begun to suggest new designs that would represent their destinations instead.
The huipil should honor our neighbors.
The dyemakers are flourishing, and rich colors and strange smells are everywhere. There are many ways for local talent to benefit from these fresh opportunities.
A newly elected governor has earned the people's fervor. With her impassioned speeches, she seems adept at riling up the people.
Whip up their enthusiasm for war.
The young scribe presses her stylus into the clay tablet. She is the first of her people to commit this particular tale to text, though not everybody sees this progress as positive.

Word spreads of a particularly ruthless militia commander who demands most vigorous training. The soldiers complain in secret – their work is done only by necessity. Would a gentle hand not encourage more volunteers?
The apprentices are up in arms, demanding fairer pay for their contributions at the workshops. "These young people!" a master grumbles. "In my day, we were grateful for the free training!"
They must pay their dues through labor.

In the planning of the new temple complex, there is a foundational disagreement: should the priests design for the kind of comfort that can facilitate long hours of prayer? Or reinforce, through ascetism, the privilege of being close to the divine?
The library is inundated with a bounty of exciting new works. As overwhelmed librarians work to catalog and shelve all the material, they notice some important texts exist only as a single copy.

The library's collections are ruined by the recent storm, and many works, existing as a single copy, are lost. Fortunately, thanks to their strict organization, the librarians know exactly what was destroyed and quickly commission authors for replacement texts.
The recent storm destroys the library's extensive collections. Fortunately, another library holds copies of these texts, so no knowledge is lost.
Maya soldiers raze the village, setting fire to buildings and looting homes. Through the haze of smoke, a group of soldiers spy the enemy chieftain running into the nearby forest.
A distant celestial phenomenon shines brightly in the night sky. The portents are clear: it is time to face the enemy in a star war.
Ready the troops to wipe foes from the face of the earth.
Establish supply lines to aid Maya dominion.
The hul'che company's course of plunder turns lands inside out. One day, they come upon a quivering band of civilians hiding in a cave, clinging to each other in fear.
The scout's dog yelps, attracted to a digging-spot in the earth. By and by, the dog's busy paws unearth a cache of valuables, probably hidden for some emergency and then forgotten.
The secret cache should be re-buried.
The old soldier watches the latest conscripts in the training yard: novices, farmers and youths clumsily swinging weapons, some more eager for the front lines than others.
These conscripts are best suited to support roles.
They will soon learn their battlefield duty.

Two artists are lifelong friends, though the media they use are different. They never seem able to agree on the superior form of beauty: the shapely precision of form in a sculpture, or the intricate colors of the painter's flat canvas?
Dynamic sculpture is favored in the capital.
The palace is hung with detailed paintings.

A popular potter's clay vessels are widely in demand for their delicate styling, although their lifespans seem a little shorter than expected. The potter claims that any broken ceramics are merely the fault of bad handling on the part of their buyers.
Institute quality standards for clay goods.

The arena's blood sports just don't draw the same kinds of crowds they once did. Aging gladiators spend more time socializing on the grounds than fighting, and soon, to their horror, young people start playing their instruments in the venue.
The arena is now a music venue.
The arena could be converted into a theatre.
Clearly more innovative forms of violence are in demand.

The city streets are littered with debris, overturned carts, and spilled drinks – all over a controversial chariot competition! Eventually the charioteers themselves are urged to try to calm their rioting fans.
Introduce the sport of street fighting.

As people gain faith, the ways in which they worship begin to change. The dour halls of orthodoxy seem to be less well attended these days compared to sites of new denominations observing with stamped feet and songs.
It is more holy to preserve practices than to follow trends.
The storehouses are full of lush produce, such an abundance that there's talk of selling the surplus. Eager merchants have little patience for those sad-eyed elders unable to forget the famine days.
Preserve the surplus in case of future disaster.
The scout's map provides new perspectives on shared borders with neighboring lands. It's clear that some are situated as ideal allies, while others seem destined to end up in conflict.
Prepare for war with foreign powers.
The caravan routes have shifted the fabric of the markets, sometimes literally. New colors, new crafts, new scents and tastes flow in every day, a constant river of curiosities.

An old man in the wilderness tells any passing traveler who will listen of his youthful forest ramble with a mysterious woman in white, who had a third eye in the center of her forehead. Even now, he waits in the wild lands for his love to return.
Seek out the lady in white.
One strange day, the sun climbs to its midday peak, and then...vanishes, obscured by a disk of darkness that wipes all light from the land. The rising wails of lamentation and fear are eerie.
A great wolf has swallowed the sun!

In the uncanny dark, citizens desperately pray for the sun to return. At last, the heavens seem to hear them, and rays of pale light reach their fingers across the land as the sun begins to fully emerge once more.

Priests gather to herald the end of days, brought about by the great wolf who has swallowed the sun. But just as the people weep and hold each another one last time, the sun slowly begins to re-appear, until the daylight is again like new.
The people's prayers have been heard.
There must be an explanation for this.
The people are grateful that the sun rises every morning. They gather to thank their benefactor by sending a mighty gift to the sky. The choice of offering is made carefully.
A white horse, a kingly symbol.
Sacred water, an offering from nature.

Worshippers of the fertility god Sobek mourn the passing of his earthly offspring, the tamed crocodile Petsuchos. As priests prepare the elaborate funeral for the beloved beast, their leader declares that a reptilian successor must be selected as the next Petsuchos before the ceremony begins.
Guide the crocodile to the afterlife.

The forge god's altar is laid with craftworkers' tools that begin to draw local interest. Some say the altar's power has surely charged these tools with divine strength, that they might be used to create wondrous works. To others, removing the tools from the altar would be a desecration.
Harness the power of the tools.

A sleep-tousled priest bursts into the council halls to share his dream from the gods: archers with a new style of bow, leading the vanguard of future war! At that very moment, a second priest, also apparently spoken to in his dreams, sprints in barefoot to announce a different vision: a new, sacred spearhead shall be the people's strength! The two priests look warily at one another.

The earth trembles and the great mountain erupts, sending people fleeing as flows of merciless lava devour the foothills. Some say this is the price for settling so close to the forge of Hephaistos, while others say it's the titan Typhon, struggling to break free.
Spread the story of Hephaistos' craft.
Pray for Typhon to be restrained.

People find it a pleasure to bring greenery indoors, but when potted plants droop and die, none can agree on the reason. Arguments on plant care are tearing families apart and bringing tension to long-standing friendships.
This calls for a sacrifice to the goddess.
As the storm rips roots from the ground, the people despair that their harvest will fail. Talk of sacrifice begins to spread, and many believe it is the only way to ensure their survival.
Offer the life of the local chief.
The earth drinks up the offered blood as the people pray for renewed bounty. In time, the crops take root once more.
Ever since the volunteer's sacrifice, the harvests seem to have grown more fruitful than ever.
The sacrifice of the local governor seems to have nourished the farmland, and its bounty blooms. Such rites are not without their pains, but the people rejoice in a more fruitful harvest than ever.
Though few know the true origins of the ancient rings of standing stones that dot the landscape, their powerful aura seems to inspire legend and speculation alike.
They were built by mysterious ancestors.
They are portals to the Otherworld.

The high priestess has proclaimed that a festival for the sun will empower the army. A younger priestess stands up to challenge her, passionately exhorting that a celebration of the moon would bring wisdom to guide the people.
Hold a festival for the sun.
Plan an observance of the moon.
Craftworkers marvel at a shiny new metal called silver, highly workable and malleable. The possibilities gleam.
It should be fashioned into jewelry.
One can see oneself in the reflection...
A new green stone called jade flows into the market via new trade routes, quickly becoming a popular adornment for weapons thanks to its hardness. Superstitious folk say the jade ensures triumph.
A new order of priests has appeared in the capital. They seem to be on every street corner, calling morosely about the imminent end of days.

The messenger runs exhilarated through the gates, announcing the triumph of the army. A joyful sound reverberates, and the city comes alive – cheerful instruments, the scent of delicacies cooking, the hustle and clang of celebratory preparations to welcome the victorious soldiers home.
Honor their deeds with a feast.
Remember their heroism with a statue.
As the howling storm hits the lighthouse, its keeper tears off his clothes and stands on the balcony, screaming at the spirits in the sea-scented wind of the night.
No one should be left alone that long.
A worker files a complaint about stolen tools. The accused thief, however, claims to have found the tools discarded in a public place. Does that not make them unowned?
Finders keepers shall be the whole of the law.

A busy forge billows immense heat into the surrounding neighborhood. The confident, sweating blacksmith insists high heat transforms the very nature of iron itself, but a weary neighbor pleads: "Just dunk it in cold water, it'll harden faster!"

Two expert physicians are called in to consult for a wan, wheezing patient who will not improve. They visit the patient's living conditions, and observe her struggling mood and the poor odor of the air.
There is obviously a sewage leak.
Several soldiers have become inflicted with a writhing disease, claiming nests of snakes wriggle in knots inside their bodies.

The willow seems to do little for the snake-ridden soldiers, who coil upon themselves as death seems to draw near. However one of the sick has some cheer at last, claiming the willow has cured his toothache.[N][N]The others weakly congratulate him.

The pomegranate juice has rid the soldiers of their intestinal snakes. After a dark and exhausting night, the soldiers begin to feel their vigor returning and quickly move on, so as not to be possessed by the same snakes again.

A mysterious illness rages through the capital, claiming an alarming number of lives. The Pythia calls it punishment for the people's loss of faith, but as the shrouded bodies accumulate, desperate people will turn anywhere in search of solutions.

Warriors return from their expedition tormented by a painful rash. The ah-man's cure, a drink of four peppers, is rough on the palate, but according to the healer, the only alternative is duckweed strands.
The four peppers is an ancient cure.
The soldiers can be treated with duckweed.
After taking the drink of four peppers, the fire in the Maya warriors' skin ebbs away, and the fire in their hearts returns.
At first, the duckweed applied to the Maya warriors' rashes seems to have only a mild cooling effect. But after a while, a deep sleep overtakes them, and when they wake the burning has subsided.

An advisor holds up a cage of brightly colored, squawking parrots. "This siege has gone on long enough," he announces. "Let us attach incendiary devices to these birds' legs, so they might set alight the thatched roofs in the name of Mauryan victory!"
The enemy capital is a conflagration of burning roofs, thanks to the ingenuity of the advisor and his parrots, and a feather-decked celebration soon follows.
A handler introduces a new elephant, a particularly beautiful beast who paws eagerly at the earth and raises his trunk in salutation.
In the waving fields, the people celebrate the harvest through song and dance. Their prayers rise from the rich-scented earth to the late afternoon heavens, and in time, all grows more fruitful.
Teach these harvest rites in other communities.

Surveyors and holy people have chosen a site for the new shrine, and a priest comes adorned with color for the dedication ceremony. Worshipers are already gathering to hear how the finest materials will be used to create statues of:
Shiva, the end and the beginning.
Though soldiers' bodies lie in rows before the enemy, those that still stand do so with fearsome courage. Their cry shakes the land.
They will inspire others to join.
Their strength is in one another.

A cheer goes up at the first sail crowning the horizon. By the time the ship comes in, the crowd is dense, with little ones on shoulders, all eager for a glimpse of the further world and its goods. The port becomes...

The Khmer rains are no heartless downpours to be feared, but a gift from the gods. It falls warm, and the baray fills, promising that in the hot, dry times there will still be green life sprouting from the soil.

The commander strides into the council, his eyes flat and lifeless. He has seen too much – too much death, too much hesitation, too much cost. Resting his hand on his sword-hilt, he demands that the military assume command of the nation.
Surrender the council to the military.
Change Government to Despotism and +1 War Support on all Wars.
{1_reward} and {2_reward} but lose Highest Level Commander.
Enemies fear that the legion is immortal – when one soldier falls, another immediately rises up to take their place. Behind this awe-inspiring illusion, however, is a significant recruitment expense.
End the legend and save our resources.

With a harsh snap, the crossbow bolts fly out at the charging horses, but within seconds the cavalry breaks the line and scatters the archers. Studying the broken bow, the engineer considers how to make it faster.

In the smoldering ruins of a conquered village, the army meets a mysterious figure in an ivory mask who offers them a stack of brass tablets without a word. The tablets are covered in spirals of unknown language, condensing toward a meaningless scrawl at their center.
The soldiers will collect this treasure whether they like it or not.
They seem uneasy. Let them leave the plates.
In the ruins of a devastated village, a silver idol still stands in a forgotten temple. Though it would be difficult to move, it would also be worth its weight.

A Roman argentarius emerges from the baths, only to find that his clothes have been stolen![N][N]There is only one response to this offense: a curse tablet. He pulls out his stylus and a thin slab of lead.

The sky darkens as Ra enters the Duat, and two students, illuminated by firelight, debate his route. One declares that at this very moment, the Sun God wanders the paths of Seker. As a distant rumble sounds from the west, his friend disagrees, acting out Ra's battle with Apep.
"If there is no war in paradise, how can there be any delights there?" – Nader Shah

For the first time, war with other powers lingers on the horizon of possibility. The people are divided when it comes to how they want their leader to respond, but any stance is sure to have significant ramifications.
Meet the enemy strength for strength.

As farms grow, the search for water to supply them expands. One woman claims to have found a water source by digging a tunnel in a nearby hill, and soon the region is thriving. The volume of water that flows through the qanat will soon be more than the farmers can use.
As the Immortal draws his final breath, a shout rises among his comrades. One of their own has fallen…[N][N]Soon he will be reborn.

A young Immortal wishes to join the Elite One Thousand and earn the gold-tipped spear of their ranks. His commander says he must further prove himself on the battlefield by defeating an enemy who wields a sword or a bow.
Send his unit to fight infantry.

In his quest to join the Elite One Thousand, the young Immortal stalks the battlefield. Suddenly he turns and strikes down his prey – a hardened warrior with a shining sword. The commander is impressed, but tells the Immortal there is no gold-tipped spear to be had until he brings down a foe on horseback, all on his own.
Defeat an Infantry Unit with an Immortal.
Send his unit to battle ranged fighters.

The young Immortal, seeking his gold-tipped spear, does not even flinch as he rides down the ranger's volley, closing in on his prey and returning to his commander, seized weapon in hand. "An honorable fight," his superior tells him. "But can you defeat a horseman on your own?"
Defeat a Ranged Unit with an Immortal.

At last, the young Immortal's commander offers him the gold-tipped spear in a solemn ceremony that soon ends in cheers. He has earned his place among the Elite One Thousand, and will make the army – and his people – proud.
Defeat a Cavalry Unit with an Immortal.

"Sulis Minerva," the argentarius furiously scribbles upon the lead tablet. "Permit no health to the criminal, lest he unveil himself and surrender my robe at your altar."[N][N]The curse tablet disappears into the depths of the sacred well…

"Sulis Minerva," the argentarius angrily carves into the lead tablet. "Permit no sleep to the criminal, until he reveals himself and delivers my tunic into my hands."[N][N]The curse tablet splashes into the sacred well…

The argentarius awaits his clothing’s return in vain. The thief has kept his possessions. The bereft Roman finally gathers his coins and heads to the shops.[N][N]As he passes the baths, another option occurs to him.
Lost clothing offers a chance at new fashions.
Free clothes are apparently available at the baths.

As the argentarius waits by the shrine of Sulis Minerva, a sickly man approaches the altar. He lays a bathing robe before the goddess, begging for forgiveness and good health.[N][N]The argentarius looks more closely at the robe…it's his!
Those who suffer deserve compassion, even those who steal.
Late one night, the argentarius hears a knock at his gate. An exhausted figure shakily hands over a linen tunic. "I haven't slept since I stole your clothes…"
The gods know how to help those in need.
Few things are more powerful than a guilty conscience.

As war rages, murmurs become clamors in the taverns and market squares. The people have had enough of taking the fight to the enemy. Many demand to know where aggression has gotten them that diplomacy could not have achieved better.
Despite attempts at a peaceful resolution, the conflict climate only intensifies. A growing rumble begins to animate the people of the land, who gather their courage to retaliate at last.

Crowds spill from their shelters with a great cheer, and combatants proudly fling their weapons down as the last enemy stragglers flee. The road to victory has been bloody, and long. But the people's message of freedom rings out so far beyond these borders that the whole world will surely hear.

People quiver in the shadows of a ruined city, evading the enemy's final patrols. In a cold, candlelit room in another land, mirthless officials turn over their new-won treasures. Defeat brings many indignities, the loss of hope the greatest of these.
Where once the sounds of battle ceaselessly stirred, the fields are now quiet and still. For one beautiful morning, there is nothing except for birdsong.

There is nothing to show for the many late nights, the kicked-over chairs, the concessions warily made. The enemy hungers still, and will not be satisfied until the people's will breaks. Peace will not come while hands hold knives more readily than quills.

The people heave one final time, and the hawilt swings upright. For a moment it shivers…then settles into its platform, a symbol of power and prosperity. The common people bear bread and beer to the shade while the army gathers for the stele's sacred dedication.
Begin the festival with food and drink.

A sage advises that the incision of symbols into stone will communicate the greatness of Aksum to future generations. The inscription's content is hotly debated in the palace corridors: soldiers push for their military prowess, merchants request their economic success, and the sage suggests the piety of the people.
Aksum's influence floods the land, and monuments rise to celebrate success in trade. Some suggest inscribing Aksumite coins with mottos that will communicate might with every transaction.
Send a message with the native Ge'ez.

A boom in manuscript production encourages Aksumites to weave tales of themselves. Scribes begin to lay down the deeds of their people, so that their heroes might be remembered for centuries to come. But new stories also emerge as Aksum grows – tales of adventure, riches, and conflict.
Aksum's origins will continue to thrill audiences.
Travelers' tales are both entertaining and informative.
Strange figures garnish the fig tree bark as the Maya scribe records the world in symbols by torchlight. The people gather round, each offering an account of their own to immortalize.

As the newly built Uwaybil K'uh rises above the city, the people gather for their first ceremony within its walls, bearing sacred creations as gifts for the gods. The high priest will choose to carry the one that most honors them.
A jade avian deity clutching his chest.
A ceramic fertility god emerging from an ear of maize.

Beneath the reign of the ninth Lord of the Night, Maya astronomers gaze to the heavens. Scholars turn to the alignment of the planets to plan future settlements, while believers read the will of the gods in astral transits.
The stars will guide expansion through power and wealth.
The heavens speak divine instructions and hidden knowledge.

As Egypt prospers, the arts flourish, and small workshops start to capture daily life in clay and dye. A royal architect unveils a new method of dealing with stone that stuns the local creatives, but nonetheless will demand much of their labor.
The recently completed necropolis is the talk of the empire, and citizens travel from all corners of Egypt to admire its grandeur. Those entombed in the complex seem to have an enviable permanence.
The monuments tell the stories of the dead.
The scribes will put stylus to papyrus to remember them.

Egyptian culture flourishes, yet some say the best works of art and architecture are in the past. As a priest presents a proposal for a series of new statues, a counselor whispers that time and money could be saved by claiming older statues as our own.

New pillars rise, inscribed with Mauryan edicts and crowned with beautiful wooden animal carvings. Some artisans propose that stone would better weather the tests of time, but changing traditions is always controversial.

The matha quarter is completed, and outside the temple, artisans flock to sell their wares. While children delight in the selection of terracotta animal figurines, the priests say only goods of sacred intention should be sold in the area.
Secular art should not be sold here.
Among the Maurya, two methods of storytelling compete in popularity. Scribes narrate epics through ink, and sculptors chisel narrative into stone.
The scribes capture tales of Mauryan triumph.
The sculptors hold the knowledge of art and stone.
A scribe shows his colleagues the clay cylinder he has prepared to send a message to the Persian people. Any kind of document may be inscribed upon it to share among the citizenry.
They must be taught hard lessons from the past.
They should hear prophecies of a bright future.

A queue of artisans presents ideas for new decorative bas-reliefs. One design depicts the peaceful flora of the pairidaeza: "We should commit to stone the beauty that offers respite from the harsh world," the artist suggests. Councillors say that a relief depicting the power of the Persian throne would be more appropriate.

The Achaemenid Empire sprawls across the land, holding citizens of many backgrounds, beliefs, languages, and customs. Beneath the Persian banner is prosperity – a realm of grand architecture and endless treasure. But those who stand against Persia face only destruction.
The riches of the world live here.
There are more cities to conquer.
Dr. Rizal stands in silent awe of the towering stelae of the Aksumites, solemn markers of the buried dead. The stelae are fascinating, but tales also tell of fantastic markets to be explored.
The Good Doctor and the Mound Builders

Dr. Rizal has arrived in the capital city of the Mississippians, a culture of mound builders whose influence spread through a vast trade network. Merchants from all over pass conduct their business among vast earthen platforms topped with temples and burial houses.
Ask the merchants about their wares.
Ask the merchants about their homelands.
An Egyptian man shows Dr. Rizal how to apply black kohl above the eyes, and green below, to protect against sickness. Later, he learns exactly how much a cow is worth (140 deben).
After watching a comedy in which the women of Athens attempt to end a war by withholding affection from their soldier husbands, Dr. Rizal overhears two lingering Grecians debating its merits.
The Good Doctor in Maurya India

The ground beneath Dr. Rizal shakes, causing him to almost lose his balance. To one side, a unit of war elephants trudges across a field conducting drills. On the other, an immense heat radiates from a great forge as metallurgists perfect their latest creation.

The message of the {1_pantheon} cults spreads with the hunger of a devouring fire. But is it the cleansing flame of purification, or the inferno of persecution? Division stirs about the form faith should take – what do those in the {2_pantheon} cult say about those who do not believe?
People should worship as they like.

Piles of grain and fruit spill across the stones. Animals low in the distance. The bounty will be distributed to the soldiers, to the singers, to all who nourish and sustain the spirit of our people. All that remains is to allocate the choicest portion, the biggest honor.
Every citizen must choose for themselves.
The Good Doctor and the Might of Persia
Among the Persians, Dr. Rizal gets to know the diverse people of the great empire's armies. Their discipline also impresses him.
They thrive thanks to their discipline.

Geographers mold a land out of rice, presenting the three-dimensional map of Han territory to the court. Surveying the terrain, advisors wonder what its future holds. Will these borders grow with new settlements, or will power be consolidated in the capital?

Two scholars journeying along the Great Wall debate the first chapter of their next mathematical treatise. One declares that the relation between a circle's circumference and diameter is their most remarkable discovery. His friend pushes back, arguing that negative numbers have more important applications.
Instruct craftsmen on the uses of pi.

The once-abundant fishing sites now see more erratic results, and fishermen compete for the best spots in an ever-changing ecosystem. Most believe the ocean is fair game, but there is talk of regulation to protect the fish populations long-term for the use of all.
Let the fishermen compete among themselves.

The brick workers are beginning to struggle under their workload, carrying clay an arduous distance from the pit to the kiln. Production slows and morale drops as supervisors discuss the ideal solution.
Hire more workers to share the load.

A wiry senior brickmaker keeps throwing his bricks into the fire, and his colleagues are beginning to whisper about him. But a supervisor notices that the bricks tossed in the fire seem to harden faster.

Hard times fall on a small town, and over a sparse meal, an argument breaks out among a man and his brothers once again. "This is what comes of not investing in trade," shouts one. The others vehemently disagree, insisting leadership is best served investing in local needs.
Councillors enjoy a raucous evening of proposals and counter-proposals for how to allocate the lucky surplus from a recent economic boom.

The Mississippians gather, baskets in hand, to mold the earth according to their vision. As they bear soil and clay to each new mound, they celebrate their growth, and the future they lay for their children.
As the watonathi forges new bonds with surrounding peoples through trade, the famed potkop attracts much curiosity, both as a spiritual site and as a marvel of construction.

An archer proudly strikes a ferocious pose before the coppersmith, who is crafting a plate depicting an avian warrior. The archer's friends mock his posturing, but he feels certain that when the plate is finished, all will know and tremble before Mississippian might.
His pose captures the pride of the people.
These plates must be distributed far and wide.
A Greek poet begins composing an epic work about war and conflict. Many enjoy his work, but some prefer a more adventurous tale.
War lays bare the soul of humanity.
Only through wandering can one learn oneself.

A playwright shocks Greek citizens with her new play denouncing the virtues of an honored hero. A group of theater-goers organize a boycott and march the streets of the capital demanding the play be canceled.
The disrespectful performance should be stopped.
It is art's obligation to critique our heroes.
A great historian writes of Greece's expansion across the map. The work is an intricate exploration of the treaties and alliances that have helped build the empire.

The monsoon rains quickly fill the land with new life. As the Khmer celebrate the richness of their future rice crops, they wonder at how their growing power might be wielded to increase their weight in the world.
Hold to traditions of divine kingship.
As the waters fill the newly built baray, crowds come from near and far for the spectacle. They celebrate the liquid bounty, calling its arrival a favorable sign of the wisdom of their leadership.
The baray's opening will be remembered.
The next rice crop will be particularly rich.
From the margins of Khmer society, new localized groups begin to form, seeking more specific regional authority. Eventually, tensions between regional and centralized power are sure to form.

The Roman soldiers have earned many accolades and grow proud in their strides, apparently entitled to the city's choicest bites. Some citizens start to grumble that their authority shouldn't extend beyond the battlefield.
As Rome grows, so too does the notion of Roman identity. An influx of new visitors rapidly changes the fabric of the city, and people can't always agree on what it means to be Roman.
Rome's strength is in its diversity.
Rome should distill a national identity.

Roman citizens gather in high spirits to celebrate the festival of Fors Fortuna. Wine flows liberally, and revelers drape themselves in flower garlands. One rowdy group declares that these are the celebrations expected of an empire ruled by its people. A nearby senator retorts that Rome is guided by the Senate, and a little more gratitude should be in order.
Many voices are better than few.
The Senate knows the people best.

An Aksumite potter considers an inscription for her newest pot. She recalls the priestess’s suggestion to bless its longevity: “I am protected by the power of the Lord.” But as a troop of rowdy children tumble past her delicate wares, she outlines a different message: “The one who breaks it, pays!”
A bad harvest has hit one of Aksum's regions, and its chieftain pleads for mercy from taxation. Advisors say that swift punishment can be the only reply to those who cannot pay.
These taxes must be claimed by force.
A respite may be granted in times of hardship.

Now that coins are in widespread use, Aksum’s economy thrives. Yet minting costs only rise, prompting speculation on the weight of the currency. Would lighter coins lead to better supplies, or mere devaluation?
Each new library we build is another candle lit in the dark, growing the knowledge of our people. This powerful gathering light…
Invites great minds to our shores.

Knowledge of mathematics has begun to spread and refine, and mathematicians eagerly apply their craft toward new disciplines, as well as heated debates on the harmonious role of math within the universe.

Having studied prior texts, Jing succeeds at creating a musical scale of 60 tones, each a fifth apart. The music created from this scale reveals patterns in this world that are at once logical and beautiful.
Have a Quarter with an Academy and an Amphitheater.

Mathematicians and engineers manage to develop a method of using hydraulic power to operate the bellows of a furnace. Such a canny refinement of process will certainly result in more efficient yields.
Have a Quarter with an Academy and a Blacksmith.
Lying in the bottom of the boat is an unusual fish, covered in spines and inflated like a ball. The two fisherman consider it – the pufferfish is toxic, but it also looks...strangely appetizing.
It can be cooked with careful methods.
There may be an art to cooking pufferfish, but the two hungry fisherman do not know it. Weeks later, their bodies are found in their lonely drifting boat.
Driven by hunger and curiosity, the two fishermen miraculously devise a method of safely cooking pufferfish.
The recipe should stay a local secret.
This knowledge must be widely shared.

A young Greek woman furiously marches down the street, mentally cursing her lover, the local bear tamer, for straying with another woman. Soon that curse will be real, she tells herself as she bursts into the home of a local sorcerer.[N][N]As he begins to engrave the lead tablet, he asks the woman what kind of misfortune she wishes upon her former lover.
Such villains deserve to smell like putrid gore.
The unfaithful must suffer the loss of their livelihood.

Brimming with vengeful fantasies, the young woman carries her new tablet to the city walls. She stops at the tomb of a recently departed soul and deposits the curse at its base.[N][N]The tablet rests against the tomb, waiting to be borne by the dead to the underworld…

Brimming with vengeful fantasies, the young woman carries her new tablet to the city walls. She stops at the tomb of a recently departed soul and deposits the curse at its base.[N][N]The tablet rests against the tomb, waiting to be borne by the dead to the underworld…

As she awaits the effects of the curse tablet to strike down her faithless partner, the young woman catches sight of him laughing in a local shop with his newest girlfriend.[N][N]“That sorcerer must be a scam artist!” she exclaims, scaring several birds in the vicinity. “Although perhaps a curse tablet was an extreme reaction in the first place…”

Waiting for the effects of her curse tablet to take flight, the young woman strikes up a conversation with a stranger outside the inn. "My boyfriend, the bear tamer, is decent," this new friend says, "but he smells something awful. You, on the other hand…"[N][N]The young woman smiles – her curse tablet was only the beginning of this revenge quest.
The best paths are often the most unexpected.
Hygiene is of the utmost importance.
A beggar holds out his hand toward the young woman. It's her former lover, the bear tamer![N][N]"My business is ruined," he mourns. "I lost my bears, and cannot seem to capture more!"
The poorest of society deserve support.

There are seven houses, and each house has seven cats. Each cat kills seven mice, and each mouse has eaten seven grains of barley. Each grain would have produced seven gallons of cereal. What is the sum of the enumerated things?
"Seven houses?" a student wonders. "Seven cats?" She scribbles a number on her board...16807.[N][N]The disappointed teacher slowly shakes her head.

A scholar proudly holds up a tablet with many numbers scribbled upon it. "The answer is 19607!" she proudly declares. Her rival frowns and returns to his desk to craft a new and more difficult mathematical puzzle.
The opening of the city garden attracts large crowds with its vivid beauty. But its lush, peaceful surroundings are disrupted by a horrific discovery: a body buried in one of the flower beds.
The people and the government must work together to resolve such issues.
This is a job for the guards alone.

In the aftermath of the garden murder, guards search for clues and conduct interviews, while community leaders organize a neighborhood watch. At last a witness is found and the culprit is swiftly caught. All breathe a huge sigh of relief, and the garden becomes popular once more.
{1_reward}, but a 50% penalty to Happiness for 3 Turns.

Swift action in the wake of the garden murder quickly bring its perpetrator to justice. But citizens wonder if invasive interrogations and a desire to close the case quickly have resulted in the correct arrest. Paranoia spreads through the city.
A vault has been prepared by a society of academics and their students. They wish to preserve symbols of present society so that future generations may understand and remember their achievements.
Great treasures will impress the finders.
Cultural artifacts will preserve our ways.
Scientific treatises will provide insight into our innovation.
The march of the phalanx company draws many admiring eyes, and tales of their battlefield accomplishments abound.
The people will cheer them in a parade.

The much-admired Immortals grow ever stronger in their reputation for martial skill and loyalty to the throne. Their deeds are often exaggerated into the realm of legend, inspiring children and songwriters alike.
Toy figures of these warriors will inspire children to follow in their footsteps.
The ballads of songwriters will preserve the Immortals' deeds for centuries.

An innovative smith produces two beautiful horns of gold, wrought with vibrant patterns of people and animals. Their like has never been seen before, and those who behold the horns claim to feel a holy presence.
The divine clearly speaks through this artist.
The Good Doctor in the City of the Maya
In the Maya city, Dr. Rizal visits the military training yard to study a series of drills. As the sun sets, he discovers the miraculous stellar observatory.
The ravenous ocean swallows a ship full of sailors, their cries and driftwood scattered across the unkind waves.
Save the sailors' lives, forget the rest.

The protracted war is the subject of much debate among the strategoi. The time has come, some say, for more advanced formations to pressure the enemy. Others draw up sophisticated ambush plans as alternatives.

A trade caravan is lost in the wilderness. The merchants in charge argue over how to find their route once more. One insists he can read the stars. The other sighs. “For once, can’t you just ask?” he says, pointing to a nearby homestead.

While setting up wares in a distant marketplace, a merchant overhears salacious gossip about a local governor. He eagerly tells his assistant, who tells her friend, who tells her neighbor, who tells his cousin – the governor.[N][N]Furious at the rumor mill, he shuts down the merchant’s stall until a formal apology is received.
An apology must be made at once.
The full story must be heard!

Aksumite nobles tire of competing with peasants while hunting elephants. They request that the activity be limited only to those of aristocratic blood. The common people protest, claiming the tradition has cultural value for all levels of society.

Reports come in that citizens are being attacked by lions within city limits. Many wish for more Medjay to patrol the streets and keep the beasts at bay. A few claim that the lions simply reinforce the cycle of life.
The tide bears a mysterious gift up onto the shore, drawing a crowd of fascinated citizens. A massive tentacle lies in the sand, slick with seawater and dotted with circular mouths.

The final slinger has fallen before the enemy's wrath. In the mourning days that follow, some wonder whether this lot was simply outnumbered, or if melee combat is a safer bet than ranged warfare after all.
There was such fanfare when the scout departed, and now the music is silent, the banners flying limp. So much time has passed that the truth begins to set in: he will never come home.
The last settlers' expedition ended in disaster. Some volunteers are prepared to try again, but the community is divided. Perhaps they should be better defended first.
More and more, wealthy people wear the fashions and display the arts of the neighboring land. Their language is being practiced in capital schools, while local crafts are the butt of jokes.
We have much to learn from these new neighbors.
It is an act of war to erase our ways.
A philosopher proposes inscribing the cornerstones of the monuments with a message, so that all who pass through here may know what is most important to its people. The final carving is:
"Let all embrace non-violence, and live in peace with one another."
"Let all see the wisdom of the Dharma."
"Let all religions thrive under the great Wheel of the Dharma."
The Good Doctor and the Rumored Lands
Time and again, Dr. Rizal hears of rumors of faraway lands and peoples yet to be encountered. It could only enrich our own to learn of others’ ways, some say.
The Good Doctor and the Rumors Confirmed
The realms of this age have bestowed their secrets, and Dr. Rizal returns home.
The Good Doctor and the Rumors Confirmed
The gentle waves of the baray lap the shores of the greatest temple built by human hands. Serenity reigns. It requires one more crowning touch.
Build a stone library for the high priest.
Build a shrine to house the vajra, Indra's sword.

The storm brings unprecedented rain, and a landslide reveals a jumble of bones with a great arching spine, longer than any animal we have ever seen. It can only be the Horned Serpent of our storytellers’ tales, a poisoner that died once – but will not stay dead.
Warriors will carry shards for luck.

The seat of authority has traditionally been shared among representatives from different towns. But some have begun to argue that those who live in the capital are better poised to delegate issues to the rest, and their voices are growing louder.
The Good Doctor and the Khmer

Dr. Rizal is not surprised that so many Khmer customs revolve around water, given its abundance. His guide nods at the remark, and notes that they would not benefit from such plenitude if the surrounding lands had not submitted to their king.
Do a survey of the land.

From the shadows of the forest, strangers emerge. Yet somehow their faces are familiar ones, each the twin of a local person. Identical pairs greet one another, some with wonderment and longing, and others in abject terror.
Cast off these spirits from the Underworld!
The Good Doctor Meets the Romans

Dr. Rizal meets many Romans, all of whom boast about taking the best parts of the cultures they conquer and integrating them into their own. In the Forum, he joins lively and longstanding debates on the nature of national identity.
Rome is defined by its international population.
The strength of the conqueror presides here.
Some of Aksum's fighters fear the new metal, believing ironwork to be akin to witchcraft. The materials are always wanted, but the forges are never welcome.
Establish the ironworkers in the capital.
The Great Wall stands in defiance to the enemy, but it also watches over all the trade that passes through the area. Talk of opportunity is on everyone's lips.
Open our borders and collect a tax.
A great white elephant rears up in its shackles, testing the strength of the hunting party that holds it in bondage. This rare creature is a holy symbol of royalty, an expression of its ruler.
It shall be a royal ornament.
It shall be a royal war mount.

The pleasure gardens have blossomed into a beloved part of the social fabric, and a cultural emblem in their own right. Their constant flow of water creates a feeling of security. But such thirst is relentless, and some might even call it wasteful, even if they only whispered it.

The ground shudders, and a terrible wail rises up. A granary has collapsed, killing a mother and child who sheltered from the midday heat in its shadow. Family members scream and beat the earth. Why? Why these innocents, standing in such a precise place?
Unseen forces act with unknown agendas.
Soldiers return from the field with fever-bright eyes, bringing lurid descriptions of slaughter and disembowelment that frighten children. Even the new conscripts are unsettled.
Send them back to the battlefront.
Each clan carries an image of an animal to represent themselves. The people convene a raucous council to determine which clan should lead all the others.
As the plow cuts into earth, it turns over soft and black, foretelling a rich growing season. During the festival rites, the people will bless the soil for the year ahead.
For a day, the nobles become fools and the fools become nobles.
The finest lamb is returned to the land.
The ground is nourished by human blood.

A beleaguered centurion comes before the Senate, trailed by a clamor of voices sharp as swords. These poor landless men are denied the honor of fighting for Rome, he says. The army needs them. Abolish the property requirement so that these citizens may serve, while their zeal still lasts.
The consuls have received word from a faraway backwater. They wish to send some of their civilians for training by the Roman legion, that they may defend the empire.
Better for them to send gold.

At the temple of Mars Ultor, the priest is well-known for his thunderous lectures on how the Roman god of war is distinctive, utterly different from the war gods of neighbors. Gathered before the temple's open doors, devotees often whisper among themselves, wondering what, exactly, he means.

Like fire blazing through the insulae, a new commemoration of the latest war spreads from hand to hand, purportedly the latest in a series by the Roman leader. The text is mangled and deplorable. But it spreads the glory of the Imperator, even if its author took some liberty with the truth.
The voices of harmonious song and uplifting dialogue float above the amphitheater on its opening day. Every part of the day's program has been meticulously planned, a feast for the Roman character.

During a long-awaited visit, an important diplomat is brought to see the city's current most fashionable play. Unfortunately, the entire play lavishly celebrates how the diplomat's nation was crushed in the recent war.

At last, the great Colosseum is unveiled, a monument to spectacle built to stand the test of time. The day of its first event is a wonderful chaos, with visitors traveling from far and wide to queue in the city center in the hopes of being part of cultural history.
Unveil a new drama celebrating the Caesar.

The sacred Oracle site is thought the be the mouth of the gods themselves, and so many pilgrims journey to hear those voices that their footfalls begin to transform the land. Those who have lived at the site all along bemoan the new world that suddenly surrounds them, but the gods have always demanded change.
Entrust the site to the local community.
The Oracle belongs to all of Greece.
A legion is destroyed, its commander defeated. The eagle standard is lost; Roman honor is impugned. The generals clamor for something to be done.
Forge a new standard and pretend it has never been lost.
Form a new Legion to recover it.

Stories are told and songs sung in tribute to the soldiers' victory over the enemy. Roman children proudly craft their own toy eagle standards from sticks and cloth, knocking the heads off their dolls.
The standard is only a symbol. Roman pride endures.

A man erects a massive stone in commemoration of his virtuous wife, who managed his affairs while he was in exile. Now that he has returned from disgrace, the monument is a flashpoint of discussion on civic virtue.
Move the stone to an honored place.
A comet streaks across the sky, bright fire in the gloom. Citizens murmur: surely it is a portent. But of what?
War. It is time to prepare.

At long last, the tools fall silent and the amphitheater stands proud once more, its restoration a celebration of how the city's culture has endured. With much enthusiasm, crowds flock to see the first event since it was destroyed.

It is the stuff of nightmares: the approaching thunder, the crack of splintering wood, and finally a tremendous crash. Amid the dust and smoke stands a proud, tireless elephant – the purabhettarah, the city-breaker.
A grinning pilgrim, hands scarred by forge-fires, claims the skill to craft a blade so sharp it can split a hair lengthwise. Soon all the smiths in the city have placed their bets.
Give him a hammer and a lump of tin, and have a laugh.

A murmuring crowd of smiths, nobles and merchants gathers to see the long-awaited work of the pilgrim's forge: a steel rippled like a river, that sings in the air as it cleaves a single hair into two whisper-thin strands.
A debate begins between rival groups in the academies over the nature of the body and soul. Which should take precedence?
We are spirit first, and material second.
There is no spirit, only bodies.
There is no essence in itself, either spirit or body.
The people look at one another and ask: who are we? Their cultural heritage deepens.
Progress marches on, driven by discovery. The people's thirst to know the workings of the world cannot be quenched.
Wealth flows through the land like a river, offering up priceless nourishment: economic security.
Strength is best measured by the skill of its use. Wisdom sharpens power's blade.
Duty to one another is duty to the self. Diplomacy grows more powerful with practice.
Over the horizon, there is always another horizon. Reach grows like the dawn.

An increasingly popular orator has been agitating night and day, claiming that Delian and Peloponnesian mindsets are inherently at odds, and that civil war is inevitable. One night, a hooded figure is seen in the stoa, whispering in the orator's ear.
Does It Pay to be Complicit?
Word breaks out that an elite officer who has violated policy will not be disciplined. Amid investigations and disagreements, the officer’s supervisor is found to have accepted a bribe.
The officer's work is worth more than his crime.
This is a betrayal of Confucian teachings.

On their coming of age day, a young citizen stands conflicted at the threshold of home, wringing hands callused by duty. Family is sacred, a unified household divine. But what if somewhere out there in the world, a new life waits just for them?
They must follow their own path.

Society evolves in cycles, and new generations always bring radical ideas. Women consider how to start providing for themselves, while children start to visualize a life outside the duties of their generational homes.
Maintain the stability of the familiar.

A philosopher considers a group of passing merchants, all of whom smile and wave. Considering their similarities, the philosopher plunges into deep thought: "If the end goal is to be a good person, does that not make us all Junzi? Does it make us all the same?"

The soldier exhales slowly and rests the nu against their hip. Target in sight, the soldier cocks the lever forwards and back, releasing a slew of arrows in rapid succession. They look like shooting stars dancing across the sky.
Train more soldiers to use the nu.
Layers upon layers of brick and stone fortify the second Great Wall. An immovable force, a reminder of the lengths the Han will go to in order to protect its residents.
Build a garrison to watch over the wall.
The city center is bustling with activity. An urban planner looks up from their blueprint to take in the action. With such fast growth, the residents here will need more facilities.
The city planners carefully diagram every sector, candles burning into the night as they decide how to allocate their development budget.
Two exhausted scientists decide to try one last experiment before they take a break. Uneasily, they consider the risky lime. Any mistake could have lethal consequences.
The envoy became the village's new Suzerain, and all the doors of its knowledge opened before them. Suddenly, there was a wealth of scientific knowledge to apply toward never before-seen projects.

An astonishing bowl, coated nearly thirty times in gleaming lacquer, sits on a work table as its artisan meticulously carves a pattern of hibiscus. Fellow carvers look on in hushed awe, never having seen the like.
The poet puts down the brush for a moment to reflect on their next yuefu. The topic matters much, if the work is to be as charged and resonant as it needs to be.
A Palace Fit for the Imperial
The recently constructed Weiyang Palace looms massive, drawing all eyes and stories for miles around. The first to build such a marvel should surely decide how it is experienced.
Open Weiyang Palace to the public.
Events at Weiyang Palace are for the elite.
Drunk on rice wine and a little careless, a convict or two went "missing" from a labor gang. Now there are rumors of a rebellion, a chance for a new dynasty.
A triumphant envoy presents Queen Himiko with a gift from a new ally: enough bronze mirrors that every wall would reflect her visage.
Display the mirrors in good faith.
A battle won, but no time to celebrate the victory. Expansion demands resources in the form of trained soldiers, and it's up to Tubman to replenish the army.
Recruit the most enthusiastic volunteers to fight.

An actor plays the role of a bumbling ruler, tripping over their clothing and knocking a plate of food to the floor in a show of physical comedy. The audience laughs, apparently finding the material all too relatable.
Shoulder to shoulder they march, forming an impenetrable body in perfect rhythm. No enemy escapes the phalanx.
Devotees surround a large tree, running their fingers over its rough bark. They believe it is the home of a lucky spirit.
Embrace the legend to attract farmers.

The chief takes up the official mantle of animal skin, preparing for the day's governing. Ever since the people passed their new laws, the work has been more about mediating disputes than leveraging authority.
Chiefs will still govern the towns.
This is now a symbolic role.
Send them to negotiate with distant tribes.

The rivers fill the bathhouses, glittering with silt and healing minerals. Word begins to spread far and wide of the water's curative properties, and soon, visitors crowd shoulder to shoulder with locals in the baths. It is not always pleasure.
The river's gift is for all.
Miracles from the holy water are reported.

Philosophers drive sticks into the ground and measure their shadow. All across the world, they say, others are doing the same – and finding different results. Some say the likely shape of the world is a cylinder. Others claim it is round, like an orange.
The sun rises and sets only here.

The Khmer farmers and astrologers alike learn the schedule of the floods, and the great baray transform the landscape to something divine. They harness the water's patterns to create a vision of the sea that washes Mount Meru's heavenly shore.
Camel trains, flat-bottomed barges and deep-keeled ships come bringing fine dyes, silks and gold for royal adornment. Amid the sea of color, howdahs sway atop marching elephants of war.
Take these goods to the palace.
These will make fine gifts for our neighbors.

The Mauryan merchants are from a distant land, but over time they have become familiar. From kshatriya to vaishya, all know the stories of Rama's heroism, of Draupadi's fury, of the antics of Hanuman and the glory of Mount Meru.
The bell simply will not ring. With each cast, it remains silent. The molten bronze seems to be calling for a human voice.
Throw a sacrifice into the bronze.
Three monks of Nalanda engage a heated philosophical argument, sweat beading on their shaved heads. They endure days of discourse to determine which school of thought is the strongest.

Each day, the traveling merchants descend from their quarter to watch the city awaken. One sits with his brush, furiously recording what he sees. He seems particularly taken by the temples of the city.

Builders scramble to adorn new construction with precious materials, and the merchants are widely impressed. They return home with legends of Khmer splendor, led to believe it has been this way all along.
The elephants trumpet glory and pain, pikes swing and crash, and flesh thuds against flesh. A great beast of war crashes to the ground, and when the dust clears, the Khmer hero remains.
The defeated commander surrenders, bright armor dulled with blood. The soldiers demand he be taken back to the capital strapped to a yoke, in humiliation. The nobles protest such an uncivilized act.

Tjaty Ahmose walks the streets as an air of unease permeates the city. It's clear there is a poverty of ma'at – the balance necessary for the functioning of the universe. Egypt needs the proper space to maintain this balance.
The priest lights the censer and steps into the shrine to perform the traditional offerings. Afterward, he sweeps away his footprints as he leaves. For one day more, ma'at is preserved.
Have an Altar and a Monument in the same Settlement within {1_turn_timer}.

Wearily, Aperel slumps into his seat after a long day of hearing petitions. A tjaty must attend to all matters of state, and is commonly pulled in multiple directions. But a common theme is emerging: the safety of Egypt's people is utmost.
An effective army is a disciplined one.
Aperel watches new soldiers train: they challenge one another, and follow the counsel of their superiors. These forces will secure Egypt's peace, or die trying.

Merchants and day laborers line the city streets, among towering buildings born from the mind of Tjaty Hemiunu and the teachings of his father Nefermaat. The people's lives grow easier, and the tjaty now looks toward something grand: enrichment of the spirit and the imagination.
Those to come will marvel at how it was made.
Its greatness is already known to Egypt.

Tjaty Imhotep looks about the great edifice of his own design: mothers cradling their babies, hucksters advertising cheap thrills, barefoot children playing with stones. Imhotep too came from humble beginnings, and his achievement is also theirs.
Tjaty Khay observes as people linger in the temple courtyard, bearing gifts for their gods. But the gods live within the temple, and only priests are admitted there.
The portable shrine attracts a greater and greater following as it moves through the city streets. As they do at their altar, the people celebrate their gods, their kings, and themselves.
Our holy sites are our mirror.
Our holy sites draw out the truth.

At a funerary rite, the living relatives of the deceased plead to Tjaty Nebet for the comfort of their loved ones. She knows as well as anyone that all souls must face the gods' judgement before passing into the Field of Reeds, but what more can one tjaty do?
Nebet watches as another family brings gifts to their loved one's resting place. In their grief, a thread of comfort gleams like gold: to know the dead will not be forgotten.
Have a Specialist on a Necropolis within {1_turn_timer}.

The residents of the worker's village Deir el-Medina return home from a long day's work, to rest for the next. Tjaty Paser is reminded that their comfort is as vital as any of the great structures they create.
Create more leisure sites for workers.
As Ptahhotep grows frail in old age, he sees wisdom faltering among the youth leadership. He will have to teach them how to preserve ma'at, if not through experience, then through his writings.
Find a worthy leader to guide them.
Leaders from all corners of society have taken to the Maxims of Ptahhotep. It seems the old tjaty can rest easy, knowing that the balance of ma'at is in good hands.
Have a Commander with a Commendation within {1_turn_timer}.
Now is the time for diplomacy.
As surely as the great river floods, the citizens must render unto Egypt what they owe. For Tjaty Ramose, ensuring that the lands of Egypt are taxed properly is foremost in balancing ma'at.
Egypt's neighbors must also be taxed.
As Egypt grows, so do its responsibilities. Under Ramose's guidance, the tax collectors go forth to do what must be done.
Tjaty Useramen retires to his private quarters, where a large ledger lies open, unfinished. All over the city they ask for the Pharaoh's support, but there are only so many skilled workers.
Useramen closes his ledger, satisfied with the decisions he has made. Maintaining ma'at is a delicate thing.
Amina's people gather behind her, ready to organize under her command. Their will is strong, but by what means will they conquer the world?
Under Amina, her army trains day and night. Their skill and bravery must be honed like a blade, to be wielded with deadly precision.
Trade connects Amina's realm to many empires, and upon their riches she will rise to the top.
People say the forges of Amina have been blessed by some divine force, and that every hammer strike is the heartbeat of her people.
This power finds purpose in the smiths' blades.
The weapons forged by the blacksmiths find their true purpose on the field of battle. Bolstered by their fine work, Amina's soldiers march to victory.
The smiths channel this force into works of beauty.
Gold streams forth from Amina's farms, in millet and in coin. Every beast of burden carries grain instead of soldiers, and enrichment spreads.
Caravans will bear this bounty from farms to markets.
The harvest from Amina's farms finds buyers both locally and abroad, gilding the land with golden grain and gleaming coin.
The harvest yields a boon far beyond the granary.

The monk's sermon concludes: renounce violence, embrace loving kindness, and become the paragon of the world. Ashoka ponders – as a king, he has the world already. What more would make him the wheel-turning monarch, the chakravarti?
He will become the devaraja, the gods' avatar.
The borders of Ashoka's realm spread across the land, with sacred fire.
He will become a bodhisattva, an enlightened one.
The people follow Ashoka's lead in the journey to enlightenment, confident that his wisdom will build an empire of strength through compassion.

From the steps of the altar, Ashoka lowers himself into the sacred waters of the river. His people crowd on the shores, breath held as his head disappears under the water. At last he re-emerges, a new light shining from his eyes.
Holy water graces icons of the divine.
As new beliefs spread across Ashoka's territory, his people raise a cry. Now is their time to shape the world according to his vision.
Ashoka himself has grown more fierce.

Two threads of thought compete within Ashoka: one looks inward, placing all within their proper place as the great cosmic wheel turns – farmers and kings, performing the divine. The other seeks to look outward, drawing all nations into the fold.
The land must be organized for greatness.
The population swells, and Ashoka sees within the crowds a firm order. Every player performs their part in the moving of the great wheel.
It is time to take on the world.
The Senate is in session, and voices are raised in conflict. A lone senator speaks out against imperial fiat, while Augustus's supporters seek to drown him out.
The senator is allowed to speak, and debate continues on the nature of Augustus' reign. Augustus indulges their exchange…but all who gaze upon his monuments know the true source of imperial power.
Only the strength and loyalty of the army matters.
Soldiers stand tall before their commanders. They will perform well on the battlefields to come. Augustus will make sure of it.
There are greater pleasures in life than politics.
Those who can work have been sorted into regiments by their skills, and their specialities given priority. Foremost in importance are…
A new architectural marvel graces the horizon. For their artistry, Augustus' craftsmen receive highest honors from the people and the world alike.
Augustus, according to legend, is descended from Apollo. But a new cult is forming among Rome's prosperous nobles, one that places the sun at the heart of all things: the cult of Sol Invictus.
Augustus is indeed Sol Invictus, returned.
As the sun beats down on the newly built wonder, the people chant to the heavens: "Sol Invictus!" But within those two words lies only one: Augustus.
Tax these new temples like any other.
The library is stocked, and all citizens may read what they like. Well – to a point. Franklin has carefully curated what is available, to match what his people need…
Works that discuss nature and its uses.
