Franklin's citizens wander the garden, finding beauty and knowledge amidst the lush leaves and exquisite flowers.
Works of great speeches by forward thinkers.
Inspired by speeches from Franklin's library, young orators stand before the monument, composing their own addresses and delivering them to captive audiences.
Franklin arranges each month for inventors from around the realm to assemble in the amphitheater to showcase their latest work.
Franklin's exhibition of inventions brings a wave of innovative and curious new students to the academy.
This presentation is an amusement for the locals.
After each merchant returns from distant lands, Franklin listens carefully to the accounts. These, he will share with the deserving, those living...
Franklin's markets are awash with both goods and stories from around the world, enriching his people in both pouch and mind.

In Catherine's cold lands, aesthetics are a source of warmth. Travelers stir longing and wonder with stories of exquisite art, lavish courts, and the diverse fineries of foreign lands. But local folktales and poems conjure the dark of the taiga forest, and witches in chicken-foot huts.
Luxuries from warmer climes enter the marketplaces, thrilling Catherine's people and enriching the tapestry of her settlements.
By voice and by stylus, the tales of the ancient past live on in the imagination of Catherine's folk, fueling their spirits through the long dark winters.
Build a Library and a Monument.

Catherine's capital is a bright place in the wilderness, with its altars of gold and amber icons. But architects are divided on its development: is this place defined by its filigrees, or by everyday functional improvements to the urban plan?
Drama and glory will inspire all.
Crowds fill the amphitheater, conversing excitedly about the performance they are about to witness. Catherine's taste in spectacle has made her realm a destination that must be seen to be believed.
Each feast day, the old men gather in a circle near Catherine's palace and tell their tales. No mere stories, their recitations summon the values of generations.
Inspired by the tales of adventure told in the shadow of Catherine's palace, the youth embark on their own journeys, adding new stories to the peoples' legacy.
Stories of battle are most popular.
Charlemagne's procession is grand, but something is missing. More soldiers would add grandeur, but scholars beg to demonstrate their recent discoveries before king and people.
Charlemagne's soldiers march through the city. All the populace cheer as they pass, and children arm themselves with sticks and slings to imitate their heroes.
Train a Warrior and a Slinger.
If it will not take much time.

Peasants gathered to watch Charlemagne's scholars are initially underwhelmed by their awkward presentations. But when they start to demonstrate their experiments, making stones stick to one another and lighting all manner of things on fire, none can look away.
The funds for this pageantry would be better spent elsewhere.
Many peoples inhabit the land, but few yet submit to Charlemagne's rule. It is time for that to change.
The most effective diplomacy is done by the sword.
The conquered populace kneels before Charlemagne. They are now his subjects, some more willing than others – but all will benefit from his growing authority.
Charlemagne dresses as a traveling merchant to take part in the local harvest dance. Few are fooled, but all play along.
A king in disguise may learn much from his people.

Charlemagne wanders through his market dressed as a farmer. As he pauses over a pottery stall, he overhears two visiting traders discussing a new architectural method for building stronger arches. This could be useful…
This charade is just for fun.
On a warm autumn morning, citizens gather to hear Confucius speak. He encourages them to treat one another with respect, to always express care and empathy for their fellow humans.
Such compassion must be shared with the world.
The land is illuminated by Confucius' people. The glow of their settlements is matched only by the warmth in their hearts.
The libraries of Confucius are epicenters of knowledge. Within their walls, his people examine both the world and themselves.

Several advisors argue before Confucius. The empire's expansion has drawn the attention of many people, and the advisors wish to exploit their markets. But one refuses, stating that an open and honest relationship is the best path forward.
A gentle hand makes lasting friends.
Many empires welcome the envoys of Confucius, grateful that he has chosen to aid their growth rather than exploit their goodwill.
It's time to earn some gold.

Scholars tend to their codices, spending as much time caring for them as studying them. They are alarmed to learn that Confucius wishes to let the public view them directly, concerned that so much use will damage these valuable creations.

The scholars watch as people from all walks of life file into the academy to take their seats. As the murmuring stills, the first instructor stands up and begins to lecture. Confucius listens as she guides the class through new perspectives that will help them reach brighter futures.

Though Friedrich excels in war, he is a lover of art. For all his protestations, it is hard not to imagine he loves the smell of sweat and the clash of arms. But when he returns, it is to the theater he goes.
Friedrich watches as his commander drills the growing army. Soon they will meet their enemies in the field – and they will be ready.
In the peace between battles, Friedrich's wisest scholars gather in the garden, exchanging remarkable ideas from their limitless imaginations.
They are both matters of economics.
In an amphitheater clad in marble and gold, Friedrich's musicians tune their instruments: a shocking assault of brass, a delicate sortie of strings, a final volley of timpani.
This is how winning a war should sound.
Backed by the heavy beat of drums, Friedrich's army raises victorious cries as the enemy falls back. The raw melody of war rivals even that of the orchestra.
Is there nothing to be done about these acoustics?

A young, impassioned commander is brought to tears before Friedrich. Having given his men sophisticated reading materials on the art and philosophy of war throughout the ages, he has discovered that not a one of them can read!
In the courtyard of the academy, soldiers spar with one another between lessons. But as soon as their teachers call out, they file back into the classrooms, ready to expand their knowledge of war.

Tubman's agents have spent long days giving clandestine speeches in the nearby village. When its populace finally rises up, they send their old despot and his cronies running out of the gates. As she stands before the assembled villagers, they ask her for some words.
Tubman's advocacy for all – those inside and outside her borders – attracts admiration from those in need. Soon her capital fills with willing hands and loyal hearts.
The strongest messages are sent in blood. Tubman has kept her word to the villagers. Now they may forge their own path.
In the early evening, the farmlands are a constellation of lights in the dark, and cooking fires spread out across the land. Here is where Tubman's heart lives. Yet beyond the hills, dangers lurk.
Open conversation will ease these tensions.
Tubman's people celebrate the new alliance. They know that her leadership will keep them both safe and strong.
Have an Alliance with another Civilization.
Tubman finds the divine under the open sky, in a shrine made of stone. As she sits, praying to the heavens, two offerings catch her eye: an ornate knife and a pouch of coins.
Soldiers march under Tubman's command, spreading her authority – and, when merited, her mercy.
It is time to seek riches.

Hatshepsut gazes into the bronze mirror as an attendant traces her eyes with kohl. She does not look at her reflection, but beyond. The lands are as yet few in people, but abundant in possibility. Her mind reaches forward, towards…
…a network of trade, spanning the known world.
As the merchant caravan prepares to set out on its first voyage, the people wonder what marvelous goods await over the horizon. Soon they will enrich the people, in the name of Hatshepsut.
…turning her cities’ raw stone into monuments to her majesty.
The monuments of Hatshepsut draw visitors from across the known world. Her architects have created masterpieces, and their work has only just begun.

Power, for Hatshepsut, lies in the creation and fulfillment of wants. Her merchant caravans deliver fragrant hardwoods from abroad, new textiles, raw copper and tin – and her subjects crave more. In their craving, they turn increasingly to their pharaoh.
Hatshepsut's people rejoice in the bounty delivered by their merchants. They lack for nothing, and the world knows it.
Have 15 Resources Slotted across all Settlements.
They must learn to control their appetites.

Power, for Hatshepsut, lies in immortality. Stone lasts longer than memory, and her image raised in granite, with a pharaoh’s false beard and lion’s body, over time fuses her worldly reign with the divine order.
This is a story that must be told again and again, until none question it.
The architects stand back, and Hatshepsut gazes upon the pinnacle of their work. Now her name will live forever.
The people need a more rational concept of rulership.

From the altar, the peaks glow rose-red in the dusk – the order of the city below, the domain of the spirits above. As the priests admire the vista, voices of debate begin to rise like an evening chorus: what does the mountain tell us of the gods?
The streets of Himiko's settlements grow more crowded by the day. The people are drawn to Himiko's vision for the future, and they quickly adopt it as their own.
Have a Settlement adjacent to a Mountain.
They watch over the city from the sky.
Scholars perch upon the mountain above Himiko's city, watching the heavens and scrawling notes. Upon their discoveries, this kingdom will grow.
Himiko climbs the mountain, her way guided by the spirit within. With each step, her vision materializes: an empire, stretching as far as the eye can see.
In her bronze mirror, Himiko sees a world beneath her influence. But this is no longer a vision – it is a reflection of her power, spreading without hindrance.

On the day of the shrine's dedication, dawn lights the tops of the cypress trees, making a small island of gold-green foliage in the growing cityscape. The city-dwellers' donations are counted, and the bounty's allocation decided.
Local traders will appreciate a festival.
True to her word, Himiko bestows her populace with the world's riches. They want for nothing, and praise her benevolence.
Have 15 Resources Slotted across all Settlements.
Many paths lead out from Ibn Battuta's city. Some disappear over the horizon, but others wind their way to more local destinations.
The world is slowly revealed, and with it future allies and enemies. Ibn Battuta records his encounters with relish so that others may follow in his footsteps.
The neighboring land is rich with promise.
Ibn Battuta bequeaths his settlers with a map of local resources. The land they claim will soon benefit the populace.
There is no time to travel.
The scents of aromatic spices rise from hot, sizzling fat. Flavors from foreign lands begin to entice local appetites, and Ibn Battuta cannot help but indulge.
More culinary wisdom must be sought.
Merchants pursue the most exquisite foods, seeking recipes in far-off markets and bringing them home to please the taste buds of Ibn Battuta's people.
Throughout Ibn Battuta's wanderings, he has seen some strange sights. Most impressive of all are incredible machines, powered by water, that make small figures dance and twirl all on their own!

Ibn Battuta's scholars squint at the mechanisms that power the water-powered dancers. After discussing amongst themselves in hushed tones, they turn to him: "This technique is clever, but we can make it better!"
These tiny performers would be a hit in the capital.
Isabella hears the call of the divine more in silences than in languages. She holds the world in her hands, contemplating where she will be called to seek its future.
Isabella's artisans collaborate to find the best way to access the sea. Finally, carved wood and woven sails ride the winds across the waves.
Weapons gleam in the morning sun as Isabella inspects her growing army. Conquest awaits, and only the best deserve to fight in her name.
The galley groans on the waves, and sailors cheer as it begins to cut through the harbor. Swaying and lurching, it carries…
Isabella watches her merchant depart, one of many who will gather the riches of others and bring them back for her pleasure.
The horses paw the earth and flare their nostrils, impatient to depart. The cavalry are much the same, eager to live and die in the service of Isabella.
The victorious charioteers ride circles around their defeated enemies. Through their skillful combat, they advance Isabella's arm across the land.
Rizal looks out from his balcony, watching his people pass below. On such long, peaceful evenings, he contemplates the border of civilization and wilderness, and his intentions in the here and now.
A poem about home is fitting.
Citizens flock to the libraries to engage with writings about their lands. The most popular work is Rizal's own, a marvelous homage to his people.
Rizal's settlers prepare their caravan. Their expedition will create a foothold that can only lead to greater things.
At last, Rizal's great text is complete. It will be – no, it already is – his most magnificent work. Now, if only his people would read it.
Rizal's work is welcomed in realms across the land. So enthralled are his readers that many copies are sold.

As Rizal's empire grows, citizens increasingly bear witness to conflicts beyond their borders – and sometimes amongst themselves. Local politicians look to Rizal to lead by example, seeking insight on how to guide their communities. Are peaceful solutions always achievable, or must one sometimes resort to violence?
Rizal manages his diplomacy well, and his people learn much from his dealings. Their engagement with each other and the world forge new bonds of strength and friendship.
Cruel circumstance demands a forceful reply.

The advisors are at it again, arguing the same old tale of governments and their relative merits over too many cups of wine. Lafayette has had enough: "The question is not how to keep control, but how best to preserve the dignity of each person," he says.

The market is an energetic place, full of citizens hawking wares and making coin. But at the end of the day, all find their way to the garden to relax and enjoy the profits of their hard work. Lafayette's civil society provides for all.
Build a Garden and a Market.
Dignity should be claimed by the people as a right.
Lafayette's merchants rejoice in their work. The freedom to build themselves up excites and motivates them as they push ever farther in search of wares.
Time to consult the texts again.
Despite his royal blood, Lafayette has been seen by his soldiers on the front lines, handing out the blossoming cockades of revolution even as enemy arrows fly past his head.
He inspires the building of a new society.
A new masterpiece dominates Lafayette's city – a symbol of progress, and of changing times.
He inspires the people to fight on.
Lafayette has gathered around him an assembly of the oddest sort. He travels abroad often, and those he meets in far-flung lands travel to take up residence at the edges of his cities.

Discourse between Lafayette and his friends abroad results in new perspectives on leadership. They have learned much from him about governance, and now perhaps they will have much to teach him in return.
Machiavelli the advisor is jocular and quick to smile, but his smiles are carefully crafted to ingratiate. Machiavelli the ruler is as calculating as he can be brutal in pursuit of his goals.
A friend's trust is a powerful weapon.
The local populace were once wary of Machiavelli's growing kingdom, but through his diplomacy, they have come to trust his advice and generosity. What a splendid development…
Become Suzerain over an Independent Power.
Authority requires the sacrifices of others, whether they agree or not.
The burning village is a scar upon the land, a reminder to all that they are expendable pawns in Machiavelli's game.
There may be other ways to rule.
An unnamed source leaves a carefully-documented list of the crimes of a once-trusted advisor. Machiavelli pauses over the evidence, deciding that execution seems too brutal.

News of the alliance travels quickly across Machiavelli's empire. Many are surprised that a once-disloyal advisor aided in the negotiations. Machiavelli's re-education program has clearly been successful.
Have an Alliance with another Civilization.
They now belong to the army.
Rumors say Machiavelli has no great love, but the truth is that his heart is given to books on his favorite topic...
Machiavelli is a careful reader. No details escape his notice. Neither do they remain on the page – such studies are not only educational, but profitable.

Suddenly the earth trembles, sending powder drifting down from high places, and the rumble of a distant landslide hangs in the air. Pachacuti's people glance up, and then continue their journey without fear. But where does such bravery come from?
They are the kin of the stone.
Pachacuti's merchants possess deep knowledge of the land. They travel quickly to deliver wondrous goods that delight the populace.
They are the chosen of the sun.
The warriors stand before Pachacuti. They are ready to serve the sun, and ensure its rays cover all the world.
They simply know that life is short.

Pachacuti holds a handful of coca leaves towards the shadow of the mountain peak. A brisk wind blows down from the heights, reddening his face even as it invigorates his body. His people wait for his revelation.
The altars are surrounded by devotees bringing offerings to the ancestors. Pachacuti joins their prayers, and together they kneel in sacred silence.
A star falls across the heavens, its momentary green fire lighting everything beneath in the blaze of day. The soldiers cry out, wondering how to interpret this sight.
As their enemies flee, the warriors of Pachacuti raise their hands to the sky. Truly the falling star heralded their magnificent victory.

A general, face webbed with scars, pounds Trung Trac's council table: there can be no true independence without expansion, he insists. An architect with steepled fingers shakes his head, claiming a strong local culture is the only path to freedom.
Many of the defeated villagers flee. But some, impressed by the conduct of Trung Trac's army, ask to join their ranks.
Citizens congregate at the monuments, admiring their fine craftsmanship. United together under the leadership of Trung Trac, they all agree that freedom awaits.
The future is not certain enough to decide.

Expansion is inevitable – but with it comes conflict. A local clan offers expertise in novel battlefield tactics, but the soldiers clamor for improvements to the barracks, desirous to strengthen the existing forces before recruiting more.
Victorious soldiers emerge from the battlefield leaving only fallen foes behind. Their new tactics have proven successful – such knowledge will be valuable in wars to come.

Philosophers gather in the library, debating lessons from nature in hushed tones. As Trung Trac listens, one scholar holds out a smooth stone, untouched by fire or calamity. All pass it around in wonder – where does a stone's strength come from?
Its resilience is sustained by its homeland.
Trung Trac takes the scholar's stone, staring at its smooth dimensions. "A stone is only as strong as its environment," she declares. "Every individual, too, is only as strong as their community."
Xerxes' subjects have taken to calling him Shahanshah, the King of Kings. Yet the courtiers that gather daily to sing his praises will not be outdone: truly, he is Ahura Mazda, the god of fire!
Artisans unveil their monuments to the masses. It is through their handiwork that the great king Xerxes will be ever present in their lives.
The people travel to the altars of Xerxes. Their gifts are divided between their local gods and their divine ruler.

A radical philosopher arrives at court, presenting an idea of the heavens as a series of interlocking spheres, where the lesser revolves around the greater. A trim sycophant, beard neatly pointed, compares the greatest of these spheres to Xerxes himself. He describes a system where each part orbits...
The merchants of Xerxes spread his name across the earth. Most understand that their kingdoms revolve around his supreme being. The rest will find out soon enough.
The god of fire can bring light, can cleanse and warm, can cook what is raw. But fire spreads, too, voracious and unslakable. The soldiers of Xerxes...
The fire of Xerxes ignites the land. Its light shines in his soldiers' weapons, rendering all they touch to ash.

After years of diligent study, one priest has recorded the ritual movements of the stars into a folded bark-paper book. Studying the patterns of Chak Ek' – and how this great star rises and falls in balance with the sun – could predict the prosperity of future events.
Good fortune will appease the people.
This holy study must be preserved.

With a start, a chieftain awakes from restless sleep. In dreams, they were visited by the Birdman, a powerful warrior holding a rattle fashioned from the skulls of their enemies. Before traveling to the Upperworld, the Birdman promised to retrieve the souls of the chieftain's kin from the realm of the dead.
Preserve this account through engraved images.
Immortalize the dream through ritual dance.
The Good Doctor and the South-Pointing Spoon

A fortune teller stops Dr Rizal in the street, presenting a "south-pointing spoon" balanced on a bronze plate. They say it can divine his future, but its certainty about the southern direction is fascinating in itself.
Explore its uses for navigating wilderness.

Satisfied at last, the writer sets down their quill. They have spent countless hours writing down words only to scratch them out and rewrite them. All will be worth it if just one reader finds joy in this text.
One must write every day to improve.
Inspiration only strikes when it wills.
The massive amphitheater is an open-air marvel, constructed in natural harmony with the very earth beneath it. Each new event, be it drama or sport, fills the seats quickly.
The amphitheater was made for plays.
The place is a new home for sports fans.
Ambition drives innovation – with still so much to discover and explore, mastering a skill becomes the work of a lifetime.
Mastery is found through meticulous research.
Luck plays a role in all endeavors.
Amina is most at home in the unforgiving deserts, and she has thrived by setting up trade routes through the sand. Her success in inhospitable lands has become a hallmark of her rule.

The reformation has been a long and difficult process, but little by little, the infrastructure improves, and soon the streets are full of tourists. Like a thread that sparkles in weaving, the city's vibrance grows.
The city is enriched by its visitors.
The city impresses with its structure.

Incredible sounds reverberate from the amphitheaters, symphonic waves that beckon from all corners of the city. The music is beautiful when it vibrates underfoot or beckons from a narrow road, but to take it in as an audience member is a pleasure that draws visitors from far and wide.
The concert experience is a key cultural form.
Gold is so abundant that it is practically an influential citizen in its own right. Buildings glitter with seductive gilding, and wealth whispers in private halls.
Make luxury a beacon to all.
The city now has more gold than ever before, heralding an economic boom. Everywhere it touches brings prosperity – but isn't there a warning tale about turning all things to gold?
Lock it away in the coffers.
As citizens become soldiers, homes become barracks. The way of war is in every heart, and comfort is easily traded for utility: a military city is surely one that can never be felled.
Give prime housing to the commanders.
The soldiers all have run of the city.
Empty plots become stables, where horses are bred for war. The children of this city ponder why the four-legged beasts cannot be pet, for they are shaped like friends.
All ride for the same purpose.

This city will be home to the best and brightest, with the library as the epicenter of discourse, serving as a place of research. Scholars will be made here, and they shall usher in a new wave of discovery.
Give study all the time it needs.
Research is worth little without application.

The academies have become the city's beating hearts, alive with controversial breakthroughs and scandalous research papers. Long may it stay the same, the pursuit of knowledge turning the wheel of all things.

A new play proudly proclaims life is meaningless and happiness is a delusion. Critics have declared the performance a depressing farce, but the public returns to the show in droves. Is civic morale on the decline?
Inspire the people with a public work.
Inspire the people with a tournament of athletics.

The manager of a portable food stall has been peddling wines and meat pies to a mob of political protestors. However, the drink has further excited the crowds, which overturned the stall and set it ablaze.
Outlaw drinking near the civic center.

Under the shade of trees, young men listen as a woman lectures on pleasure: It is taught as the highest good, and therefore some suggest there should be no limit on its pursuit. But without foresight, such hunger leads to diminishing returns – and eventual ruin. "How," the woman poses, "should one conceive of pleasure forestalled by the law or by custom?"

A group of students arrives from beyond Greece's borders, prepared to absorb Arete's knowledge and recirculate it among their own thinkers. "Our students interpret our philosophies differently," she tells them. "Which of our doctrines interest you most?"
Improve 2 Wine Resources and have 2 Academies.
The pursuit of happiness means freedom from pain and sorrow.
The pleasures of the mind are greater than those of the body.
Duty to one's people is its own pleasure.

The city's cobblers are exhausted. Students come at all hours, begging for their shoes to be resoled. Aristotle's teaching style requires they follow him on his walks, conversing as they attempt to categorize the world around them. These walks are key to the future of philosophy, but the costs of a cobbler's rush work is more than most students can pay.

A cacophony of animal sounds fills the area around the Lyceum. At last, Aristotle can expand his early work on natural biology! Looking over the many different creatures brought from all corners of the empire, Aristotle wonders where to begin.
Gather 3/4 of Hides, Camels, Wool, or Horses.
Document the physiology of individual animals.
Surely the students can walk barefoot.

An upstart foreign courtesan and her radical ideas are becoming a topic of mockery for playwrights. She is unbothered at the discomfort she sows within the order – she is a popular banquet guest, and her speeches are well-attended. Perhaps a new depiction of her would sway those uncomfortable with her influence.

Aspasia's influence has only grown, and her symposia attract the greatest thinkers and artists of the day. Wine flows late into the night, and lyres mingle with the chirping of crickets. Citizens flock to her for incisive wisdom on how to live well. Her most popular event is on...
Improve 2 Wine Resources and have a Specialist on a Villa.
The intersection of love and virtue.
The distinction between legality and morality.

A promising poet's love poems, set to the music of a lyre and inflected with a unique dialect, have become fashionable in the right circles. Her works are woven through with desire: of young women pining, of separation, of the beauty of the female form.

Sappho's poems have become enshrined among other influential works as an inspiration for the Greek people. Her distinctive voice is unique among the great writers – though some say her dialect is a bit provincial.
Greek individuals' uniqueness should be encouraged.
Her voice should set the standard.
Her poetry is lovely, but there are larger concerns.
The great Pythagoras is a much-desired dinner guest, although it is said he will not eat any chicken. All have much to learn from him.
Pythagoras' lessons have caught on. New philosophies flourish, inspired by his teachings. But some citizens fear that his wide range of influence will limit new ideas.
Have a Quarter with an Academy and a Library.

Justice, social virtue, piety, wisdom: Plato writes tirelessly of conversations among leading intellectuals, exploring but never settling on a single definition. Instead, he proposes that all tangible experiences are but the shadow of the ideal Forms of these concepts.
Explore the concept of Forms in detail.

As Plato's ideas spread, students grumble, their hands cramped from writing. What does he mean when he speaks of bees, they ask? Should they write their own commentaries on their interpretations of his meaning, or should they give up and simply keep transcribing?
Write commentaries. One should be in dialogue with dialogues.
Fascinating. But there is a state to run.

The boundless enthusiasm of Hypatia's pupils often means the palace and the city center are virtually overtaken by her scholars, linking arms and putting heads together. Wherever they go, scientific curiosity becomes a watchword, but there's also a dense crowd.
Let them stay at the palace.

The building's halls echo with curious voices. Hypatia's openness has fostered the flourishing of ideas, traditional and heretical, from sources near and far. This inspires the populace: some in surprising ways.
Students ambush bath-goers to discuss philosophy in the water.
New absurdist plays exploring scientific theory are performed.
The scholars of the academy can learn much from them.

What is virtue? Is it like a shape, or like a swarm of bees? Socrates' oft-infuriating questions provoke those who seek clear answers. Some find his refusal to clearly promote state virtues impious, while others see an opportunity to create radical new frameworks of understanding.

Socrates' teachings have spread like fire through the capital. Old men mutter in the agora: the youth would be more invested in improving the republic if that ne'er do well philosopher weren't constantly filling their heads with questions. Something must be done about him.
Let the ephors decide his fate.
He shall be tried by a jury.

The mathematician's stylus drags a line through the wax tablet, alongside a previous one. He insists he is on the verge of a breakthrough, but something far larger – and grander – must be built to test his hypothesis.
A monument to last aeons will be built.

In the shadow of the wonder, Thales lays out a marked length of rope. He instructs an onlooker to etch the end of the mathematician's own shadow in the dirt, and turns to frantic calculations. At last, he emerges with the height of the wonder: and the first theorem on proportionality.
Use his theorem to build more...and faster.
Mathematics can be proved with simpler methods.

Of late, many soldiers are not spending their evenings in raucous revelry, but in quiet study. Xenophon's prose is remarkably readable, and the literate among the group absorb his lessons on historical warfare eagerly.

The military academy is a success. Even soldiers who cannot read learn from those who study Xenophon's work. With many readers, however, come many interpretations. Two of Xenophon's most ardent readers disagree on the most important lesson their troops should learn.
Have a Quarter with an Academy and a Barracks.
The educated should be given command.
A united army is an organizational body, not only a fighting force.

As grim stragglers march home, a weary Xenophon weaves a tale of loss leagues away: of desperation and thirst and despair, and finally, at long last – the sea. Xenophon's audience takes many lessons from his tale, but one is chief among them...
Without wise leadership, a large group cannot remain concordant.

In a shower of cinders, an entire quarter burns. After the ashes cool, soldiers pick through the remains – some impressive foundations have withstood the fires. At the same time, they notice a group of survivors carrying off supplies.
Detain the survivors. These are {1_CIVILIZATION_ADJ} supplies.
Let them go. These foundations need examining.
Ban Zhao is unimpressed by the library. She walks up and down the halls, feeling pity for the texts collecting dust. What this city needs is an institution worthy of housing her essays.
Prose should be displayed as art.
Ban Zhao greets citizens entering the museum, smiling at the child waddling alongside their mother – how delightful to see a curious mind about to be exposed to the wonders of art for the first time.
Books belong in libraries, of course.
The court is abuzz to greet Han Fei. A renowned philosopher and aristocrat. Royal blood runs through his veins, but does not stain his work. Envoys wish to make an offering reflecting his merit.
Gift him a collection of political essays.
Offer him a private tour of the palace.
Laozi examines the scholars. They’re expecting a sermon, something profound and wise. Which version of Laozi will they get? The contemporary of Confucius, or the humble court astrologer?
Discuss the writing of the Tao Te Ching.
Philosophize on the preciousness of life.
Students flock around Mencius, asking him how it feels to be compared to Confucius. A concerning question – he is his own man, with his own teachings.
The youth need more educational institutions.
Hammers ring on bronze outside of the libraries of Mencius, that each will bear a plaque with his name. All who enter will bear him in mind first as they read Confucius' philosophical pamphlets.
Comparison is the highest form of compliment.

Dozens of philosophers follow Mozi wherever he goes, anxious to settle down and devote themselves to his teachings. A city with too many bodies and not enough resources can hardly offer a grand welcome to scholars.
Build more dormitories to house scholars.
Create research roles to supplement scholars' incomes.

The law cares nothing for status or family ties, even while politicians beg for its mercy. Punishment must never be biased, and Shang Yang feels it keenly: if he cannot stick to his own convictions, what does that make him?
Arrest the familial traitor and keep the bounty.
Keep the familial traitor as a spy, closely-watched.

The king receives a contingent of builders, all looking for work. Shen Buhai leans in to whisper, choosing his words carefully: any suggestion in the royal ear must sound like the king thought of it first.
Huo Qubing takes stock of the rebels: a small but fiery group, wielding fragile weapons improvised from whatever they could find. The general must decide how to deal with these rebels.
Able bodies should not be wasted. Assign them to hard labor.
Xun Kuang feels dozens of eyes on him as a scholar asks him an impossible question: are humans born inherently good or evil?
Nature and nurture each have a role to play.
Xun Kuang waxes lyrical about the human condition, hoping to inspire his scholars to think both empirically and analytically.
Have a Specialist on a Library within {1_turn_timer}.
Scholars should debate this among themselves.
Zhang Heng adjusts the water levels for the clepsydra clock. The prototype, an armillary sphere suspended by several bronze dragons, twirls patiently as it awaits its use.
Build another as a celestial guide to the seas.
An artistic piece of tech is both beautiful and functional. Zhang Heng's armillary sphere serves to assign meaning to the stars.

A luxuriant and vivid new shade of purple has become all the rage among dye-makers, who claim it is made by blending the tears of a basilisk with ground-up sea snail shells. The color's awe-inspiring effect has provoked enormous demand.
It shall be reserved for the nobility.
Deep blue indigo dyed cloth rolls out of the mills, patterned in complex shades of white and blue.

A trader stops in front of a merchant’s stall, tempted by samples of a crystalline material. The spice is briny and sharp on the tongue. “Salt from Aksum,” the merchant says. “If you have wares to sell, they are the kingdom to trade with.”
At his private altar, a priest offers incense in a small dish, preparing to spend a quiet moment with his chosen deities. He inhales deeply as notes of frankincense and myrrh fill the dimly lit room.
Nothing can take away the camaraderie rooted deep in their bones. A bittersweet goodbye, made endurable by the long-awaited promise of a loved one’s embrace.
A battlefield nourishes the soil with iron. Deep within the layers of earth, life begins anew – remnants of the human cost of war feed into an endless cycle of loss and revival.

Storm-felled mangoes lie in heaps, their skins splitting under the sun. As the scent of fermenting fruit gathers flies, farmers survey the damage, their attention drawn to a cluster of untouched trees at the center. A trick of the landscape – or is some spirit protecting these trees?
Use fruit from the remaining trees to replant.
Preserve the grove as a farmer's shrine.
Potters sit idle, their unfired wares gathering dust beside cold kilns. Meanwhile, the nearby brickworks devour wood with an insatiable hunger, driving fuel prices ever higher.

The workers move in rhythm, beating, soaking, and processing flax into linen. But with the granary and its stores now ruined, a quiet dread settles in: how long can the landowners profit from flax while those toiling in dust have nothing to fill their mouths?
Duplicate granaries will protect future harvests.
Profits remain - as always - of prime importance.

Imported rubies have flooded the market, commanding high prices and influencing court fashion. But in the capital, an aging lapidary holds a stone too close to his candle-flame... and notes how the color blackens in the heat. A fake!
Purge the market of false stones.
Ensure the old man stays quiet - these are profitable.
The rice harvest falters, overtaxed soil being asked to produce more and more for even the farthest settlement. The new grains are tough, bitter, and small. The land needs rest.
Local overseers will ensure proper crop rotation.

After discovering that burnt lime seems to enrich their fields, two farmers heave chunks of limestone into a hillside kiln. However, as the acrid smoke rises, a quarry master storms forward, fist raised, accusing them of stealing stones set aside for the construction of a new bathhouse.
Permit the farmers to purchase lime.

As tin prices soar, blacksmiths turn to arsenic to forge their bronze. But now, their heads throb, their skin blisters, and their breath grows ragged. The smiths blame the metal; the quartermasters blame laziness.
Pay for the more expensive tin.
Install supervisors to make sure the smiths stay working.

The llama breeder whistles, and the herd shifts as one, rippling over rugged terrain like a mountain stream. A passing caravan halts, captivated by the llamas' quiet grace. Several hands reach out instinctively to brush downy fleece.
This fleece should be spun into delicate threads.

The head priest runs a hand along the rugged fibers of a hardwood tree, feeling for unseen flaws. He inhales deeply, taking in the scent of soil and sap before declaring that these trees are too valuable for construction; they will decorate religious sites.
His grasp exceeds its reach; the wood is for trade.
Who can argue with the divine?

The city runs on meat - game hunted from nearby forests, given, the hunters believe, by the favor of the spirits. But now, even as the city grows, the forest-gods grow silent, and animal tracks scarce.
A great feast should capture his attention.
Village shrines will ensure the hunters make the right offerings.
